translation.en: Yes?
translation.ja: どうぞ

translation.en: …of people in the street, does it bother you--
translation.ja: 道行く人はあなたの邪魔に…

translation.en: Yes.
translation.ja: はい

translation.en: …when people stop in the middle, in the flow of traffic,
translation.ja: 例えば 急に道で立ち止まり

translation.en: and look at their maps or…
translation.ja: 地図を見る人や…

translation.en: Unfortunately, I'm not gonna have time to answer this.
translation.ja: 残念だけど その質問に答える暇はない

translation.en: Do people in the street bother me? Absolutely, they bother me. Here is why.
translation.ja: 道行く人は全員 邪魔よ 一応 昔は作家だったし 声明文でも書こうかしら

translation.en: I feel like I should write a manifesto. I used to be a writer.
translation.ja: 一応 昔は作家だったし 声明文でも書こうかしら

translation.en: That would… The title of which would be, and this is kind of an advisory to these people that you're talking about,
translation.ja: 道行く人への忠告にもなる そのタイトルは―

translation.en: Pretend It's a City.
translation.ja: 「都会人になりすませ」

translation.en: Okay? Pretend It's a City.
translation.ja: ここは都会でしょ？

translation.en: I cannot stop for one second or stand in front of a place, smoking a cigarette,
translation.ja: でも喫煙所で 立ち止まった瞬間

translation.en: without ten people instantly asking me directions.
translation.ja: 何人もの人が道を尋ねる

translation.en: And I'm surprised by this, because I always think, Really? Do I look welcoming to you?
translation.ja: これには驚いた 私が親切な人に見える？

translation.en: There are a lot of things on the ground in New York.
translation.ja: ニューヨークの歩道は面白い

translation.en: You know, there are a lot of crosswalks, not that anyone obeys them except me.
translation.ja: 誰も従わない横断歩道が たくさんある

translation.en: I always yell at cars. You're in the crosswalk!
translation.ja: 私だけが車に怒鳴ってる

translation.en: You know, as if, like, they care.
translation.ja: 無視されるんだけど

translation.en: There's graffiti on the ground. There are ads on the ground.
translation.ja: 歩道には落書きや広告もある

translation.en: But there are numerous places in New York
translation.ja: そして多くの場所には

translation.en: where there are plaques, like, laid into the ground.
translation.ja: プレートが埋まっている

translation.en: This is something that I just love,
translation.ja: 私はこれが好きなの

translation.en: because it means that they are hoping that someone is gonna look at this.
translation.ja: だって誰かに見せたくて 埋めたんでしょう？

translation.en: I don't think they did this thinking, It's gonna just be Fran.
translation.ja: 私だけじゃなくてね

translation.en: Everyone else is gonna be looking at their phone.
translation.ja: でも皆 携帯を見てる

translation.en: It's only gonna be Fran, but she's worth it. Let's put all these plaques for her.
translation.ja: 私が見るだけでも 価値はあるでしょ

translation.en: Near the library, there are different plaques for writers.
translation.ja: 図書館の近くには こんなプレートや― 図書館の近くには こんなプレートや― 〝世界の 偉大な文学の記念〞 〝ニューヨーク 公共図書館〞

translation.en: And then there are some quotes from the writers.
translation.ja: 作家の格言もある

translation.en: I think it's pretty optimistic to imagine people are gonna read the quotes.
translation.ja: 〝本には 味わうもの 飲み込むもの―〞 人が立ち止まって読むと 思ったのは 楽観的よね 人が立ち止まって読むと 思ったのは 楽観的よね 人が立ち止まって読むと 思ったのは 楽観的よね 〝消化すべき ものがある〞

translation.en: Yes? In the back.
translation.ja: 後方の方 どうぞ

translation.en: Hey, Fran. Uh, I actually never heard of you before.
translation.ja: 初めてあなたのことを 知りましたが…

translation.en: - That's a good way to break the ice. -
translation.ja: 初対面の会話として いい出だしね

translation.en: Yes?
translation.ja: どうぞ

translation.en: How would you describe your lifestyle?
translation.ja: “生活様式”を どう考えますか？

translation.en: How would I describe my lifestyle?
translation.ja: “生活様式”？

translation.en: Let me I assure you, I would never use the word lifestyle.
translation.ja: そんな言葉は使わない

translation.en: Bravo.
translation.ja: 最高だ

translation.en: That's pretty much how I would describe it.
translation.ja: そう考えているわ

translation.en: What's keeping you in New York?
translation.ja: ニューヨークに住む理由は？

translation.en: People often ask me, Why are you still here?
translation.ja: 皆がよくする質問ね

translation.en: - Like, okay, where would you suggest? -
translation.ja: むしろ他に選択肢が？

translation.en: Okay, so here's the thing.
translation.ja: そうでしょう？

translation.en: If there was another place that I could think of, I would have gone there.
translation.ja: 他に住みたい 場所があれば移る

translation.en: Okay. What do you think? This is it.
translation.ja: これでいいかい？

translation.en: - Fine. - Let's do it.
translation.ja: じゃあ始めよう

translation.en: - There you go. - God. Sorry.
translation.ja: やっちゃった

translation.en: Do you remember, Fran, I said never have anybody shoot
translation.ja: 君の車や家は撮らないと 言ったよね

translation.en: - in your car or your apartment. - You told me after they ruined my car.
translation.ja: 君の車や家は撮らないと 言ったよね 車を壊されて 苦情を言った後でしょ？

translation.en: - - When I complained about the car.
translation.ja: 車を壊されて 苦情を言った後でしょ？

translation.en: Does complaining change anything?
translation.ja: 苦情で何が変わる？

translation.en: - You mean, does it help? - Yeah.
translation.ja: 苦情を言う理由？

translation.en: You mean, if I complain about the things I complain about, will they change?
translation.ja: 私の苦情に対して 物事が変わるかって？

translation.en: Yeah.
translation.ja: ああ

translation.en: Not so far. I mean, of course, I'm a young woman.
translation.ja: 変わらない 今のところはね

translation.en: I once met a psychiatrist at a party,
translation.ja: 以前 精神科医に会った

translation.en: and I said to him…
translation.ja: そして彼に言ったの

translation.en: …I cannot think of a more boring job than being a psychiatrist.
translation.ja: “精神科医は 退屈そうね”って

translation.en: And he said, You have no idea
translation.ja: 返事は“想像以上だよ”

translation.en: what it is like to go to school for 14 years
translation.ja: 14年間 専門学校に行き

translation.en: and sit all day long and listen to people complain about noise.
translation.ja: １日中 騒音に関する苦情を聞く

translation.en: So, apparently, that's what it's like being a psychiatrist in New York.
translation.ja: これがニューヨークの 精神科医

translation.en: Everywhere else in the country, people are talking about their mother, husband.
translation.ja: 他の州では家族の話だけど ここでは騒音が大問題

translation.en: No, in New York, noise. They go in. It's like $500.
translation.ja: 他の州では家族の話だけど ここでは騒音が大問題 １回500ドルで 座って騒音の苦情を聞く

translation.en: They sit there and complain about noise.
translation.ja: １回500ドルで 座って騒音の苦情を聞く

translation.en: New York is never boring.
translation.ja: ニューヨークは飽きない

translation.en: In other words, if I'm sitting somewhere waiting for something,
translation.ja: どこかで 何かを待っている時―

translation.en: like, say, oh, I don't know, a subway,
translation.ja: 例えば地下鉄とかね

translation.en: or if I'm sitting on the subway waiting for the subway to, I don't know, leave,
translation.ja: 席に座って 電車が出発するのを待つ

translation.en: Most people are on their phones.
translation.ja: 皆 携帯を見るか本を読む

translation.en: A few people are reading, but that's never been me. You know?
translation.ja: 皆 携帯を見るか本を読む 私はそうしない

translation.en: I'm sitting there, and I am just looking at my fellow man.
translation.ja: 座って ただ周囲の人を観察する

translation.en: And this is, most of the time, excessively interesting. Too interesting.
translation.ja: それは何よりも有意義で 面白すぎる

translation.en: This is what you see in streets of New York. Not just people walking and texting
translation.ja: 携帯を見ながら 歩くだけではなく

translation.en: or standing in the middle of the sidewalk when I'm trying to get through. Um…
translation.ja: 歩道で立ち止まり 人の邪魔をする

translation.en: but you also see people doing things that I know would never have occurred to me.
translation.ja: 私が絶対にしないことを している人もいる

translation.en: In other words, I don't have a phone, so I've never texted,
translation.ja: 携帯がないから メールもしないけど

translation.en: but I firmly believe that if I did have a phone and I did text,
translation.ja: メールする気持ちは分かる

translation.en: it would never have occurred to me to do this whilst walking.
translation.ja: でもこれは絶対にしない

translation.en: A few months ago… I haven't seen this numerous times,
translation.ja: 数カ月前に見たけど 今でも忘れない 驚異の合わせ技よ

translation.en: but this particular combination of things stood out in my mind.
translation.ja: 今でも忘れない 驚異の合わせ技よ

translation.en: I saw a kid riding a bike down Seventh Avenue.
translation.ja: ある少年が中心街で 自転車に乗っていた

translation.en: He was, with one hand, texting,
translation.ja: 片手には携帯を

translation.en: with the other hand, eating a piece of pizza,
translation.ja: もう一方の手にはピザ

translation.en: - and was driving the bike with his elbows. - Ooh. He had his elbows on the thing.
translation.ja: そしてひじをハンドルに乗せ 運転してたの

translation.en: And of course, I… Of course he almost ran me over.
translation.ja: ひかれそうだったけど

translation.en: Not that he noticed. That's why I noticed him.
translation.ja: 彼は気付いてなかった

translation.en: And I thought, I am a person who believes, every day,
translation.ja: その時 思ったの “私は道端で死ぬ可能性が あると思う人で―”

translation.en: I have a very high chance of being killed crossing the street.
translation.ja: “私は道端で死ぬ可能性が あると思う人で―”

translation.en: This is a person who believes nothing will ever happen to him.
translation.ja: “彼は事故は起きないと 思っている人”だと

translation.en: If you took away the texting and the pizza, I still wouldn't--
translation.ja: 仮に携帯とピザもないとする

translation.en: - And the elbows used to ride the bike. -
translation.ja: ひじで運転する技術もね

translation.en: If you gave me a bike, and I had nothing in my hands,
translation.ja: 両手でハンドルを つかめる状態でも

translation.en: and I had my hands on the handlebars, I wouldn't ride a bike on Seventh Avenue.
translation.ja: 両手でハンドルを つかめる状態でも 中心街では乗らない

translation.en: I know how to ride a bike. Okay? So I wouldn't do that.
translation.ja: 中心街では乗らない 絶対にしない

translation.en: All these things,
translation.ja: こんなことが 毎日 起きているのに

translation.en: and it's an astonishment to me that, every day, tens of thousands of people
translation.ja: こんなことが 毎日 起きているのに 多くの人が 殺されていないのが不思議よ

translation.en: aren't slaughtered in the streets of New York. - Yeah. - I don't know why this happens.
translation.ja: 多くの人が 殺されていないのが不思議よ

translation.en: It is an amazing thing, because there are millions of people.
translation.ja: 何百万人もの人が 行き交っているのに―

translation.en: Uh-- The only person looking where she's going is me.
translation.ja: 誰も進行方向を見てない

translation.en: I am the one person in the whole city who is watching where I'm going.
translation.ja: この町でたった１人 行き先を見ているのは私

translation.en: One of the worst things, you know… There's many things that are horrible,
translation.ja: 嫌なことはたくさんあるけど 最も許せないのは

translation.en: but one of the worst things is how New Yorkers have forgotten how to walk.
translation.ja: ニューヨーカーが 歩き方を忘れていること

translation.en: One of the great things about New York used to be,
translation.ja: この町にも良い面もあった

translation.en: yes, there were a billion awful people in the street, but there was…
translation.ja: もちろん最低な人もいる でも道を歩く全ての人は

translation.en: Every single person in the street knew that,
translation.ja: でも道を歩く全ての人は 他人と歩いている 意識があった

translation.en: as you're walking toward other people,
translation.ja: 他人と歩いている 意識があった

translation.en: you move a little bit, they move a little bit.
translation.ja: 道を譲り合っていたの

translation.en: - That's right. - Okay? That's why everyone was still alive at the end of the day.
translation.ja: だから死なずに１日を 終えることができた

translation.en: Now, people don't do it.
translation.ja: でも時代は変わった

translation.en: Okay, so what I do now… They don't do it because either they're on their phones
translation.ja: 皆 私と違って 携帯を見ているか

translation.en: - or because they live in a world of one. - Mm- hmm.
translation.ja: 自分の世界に浸っている

translation.en: And sometimes… I bumped into someone because they were not paying attention,
translation.ja: 注意力がなく ぶつかってくる人がいる

translation.en: and I thought, I'm gonna let 'em walk right into me.
translation.ja: 私がよけないと 不機嫌に顔を上げるので

translation.en: Um, and they looked up, like, annoyed, and I said,
translation.ja: 私がよけないと 不機嫌に顔を上げるので “実は他の人もいるの” と言った

translation.en: Other people in a hotel lobby. Isn't that astonishing?
translation.ja: “実は他の人もいるの” と言った

translation.en: - - Like, you know, what… And that's why I feel like, pretend it's a city,
translation.ja: ここは都会なのよ？

translation.en: you know, where there are other people.
translation.ja: 都市には他の人もいる

translation.en: And pretend it's a city where there are people who are not here just sightseeing.
translation.ja: その中には 観光客じゃない人もいる

translation.en: - Mm. Yeah. - You know? Who have to go places.
translation.ja: しっかり働いている人がね

translation.en: To their appointments, so they can pay for all this junk that you come to see.
translation.ja: その税金で 観光客が楽しめるの

translation.en: That neighborhood is horrible. Times Square, the worst neighborhood.
translation.ja: タイムズスクエアは最悪

translation.en: But you rarely have to go to Times Square.
translation.ja: でもたまに行くの

translation.en: So if you have to go to Times Square, usually because you have to see a play,
translation.ja: 舞台を見ないと いけない時とかね

translation.en: you think, like, I have to go see the play, and it's in Times Square,
translation.ja: タイムズスクエアの 劇場へ行く時

translation.en: and so I'm gonna try to arrive at the theater without having gotten into 75 fights with people, because…
translation.ja: 75人とけんかをしない方法を 考えないといけない

translation.en: Sometimes I will, like, figure out, if I have to go to a theater in Times Square,
translation.ja: 被害を最小限にとどめながら

translation.en: how can I get there walking through Times Square the least?
translation.ja: 中心街を通る方法を考えたの

translation.en: And I will do this even if it means walking all the way around.
translation.ja: それが超遠回りになって

translation.en: I think, Let's see. What if I walked up to 125th Street, then all the way down?
translation.ja: 北側の通りを 通ったとしても価値はある

translation.en: Then I can pretty much miss this. That's long, but it would be worth it.
translation.ja: 歩く距離は長いけど 人混みを避けられる

translation.en: The opening of Phantom of the Opera was a big benefit, an AIDS benefit,
translation.ja: 「オペラ座の怪人」の 初日は慈善活動だった

translation.en: and I was on the committee of this, but I don't remember what thing it was.
translation.ja: 何の委員会か忘れたけど 私は役員だったの

translation.en: Um, so I had these tickets to the opening of it, and so I invited my mother to come.
translation.ja: 初日のチケットを もらったから母を誘った

translation.en: And so we had these, like, you know, fantastic seats.
translation.ja: 素晴らしい席だったわ

translation.en: What people think are. In the orchestra, in the middle.
translation.ja: 舞台に近い席の真ん中だった

translation.en: My idea of a fantastic seat is in the back, on the aisle,
translation.ja: でも私は後ろの席が好きなの

translation.en: - so you can get out, you know. -
translation.ja: 退席しやすいからね

translation.en: So the second I get into the theater, I'm plotting to get out. Uh…
translation.ja: いつも退席することを 考えてる

translation.en: And I must have been the only person in New York
translation.ja: 劇の話を知らなかったのは 多分 この町で私だけだった

translation.en: who had not been reading about this, you know, because it was such a big deal.
translation.ja: 劇の話を知らなかったのは 多分 この町で私だけだった 話題だったからね

translation.en: So when the chandelier fell from the ceiling, I thought the chandelier was falling on us.
translation.ja: だからシャンデリアが 落ちて来た時

translation.en: - Oh, Fran, no. Oh… - And I screamed. I created such…
translation.ja: 私は叫んだ 当時 ネットがあれば その姿を見られたかもね

translation.en: If there was internet then, you would still be able to see this.
translation.ja: 当時 ネットがあれば その姿を見られたかもね

translation.en: - Didn't you see the movies? - I didn't.
translation.ja: 映画版は見た？ いいえ

translation.en: - I thought… - The whole-- - It goes right over. - Yeah.
translation.ja: 本当に落ちたと思った

translation.en: But my mother, of course, knew, 'cause she was like…
translation.ja: でも母は話を知っていて

translation.en: My mother said, This kid, she's always been a problem. She's still a problem.
translation.ja: “いつもうるさい子なの”と 周囲に言った

translation.en: And I was hysterical. 'Cause it came like this. I thought it was falling down.
translation.ja: シャンデリアがこの位置で 私は取り乱してた

translation.en: So that's mostly what I remember about Phantom of the Opera,
translation.ja: それ以外は覚えていない

translation.en: except, like, thinking it was unbelievably horrible.
translation.ja: 話しはひどかったわね

translation.en: You know, This is unbelievably horrible.
translation.ja: 信じられないほど退屈

translation.en: This is exactly the kind of thing that I hate. You know, um, it's like Evita.
translation.ja: この手の話は苦手なの 「エビータ」も同様よ

translation.en: Robert Stigwood, um, had this thing.
translation.ja: 私を招待したのは ロバート・スティグウッド

translation.en: Um, he in-- He was a producer of Evita.
translation.ja: 「エビータ」の プロデューサーよ

translation.en: And he invited a few people, like 25 people,
translation.ja: 25人ほどを プラザホテルに招待したの

translation.en: to the Plaza Hotel, which was still the Plaza Hotel then, not like now, which had a little theater in it.
translation.ja: 当時のプラザホテルには 小さな劇場があった

translation.en: So I went to this, I saw this,
translation.ja: そこで「エビータ」を見たの

translation.en: and afterwards, Stigwood asked me what I think, and I said,
translation.ja: 感想を聞かれたから

translation.en: Are you out of your mind? A musical about Eva Perón?
translation.ja: “エバ・ペロンの劇なんて おかしい”と言った

translation.en: - You'll be laughed out of New York! -
translation.ja: “町中の笑い者よ”ってね

translation.en: Don't do it! I said.
translation.ja: 止めておけと忠告したの

translation.en: So this is why I would never make a lot of money in the theater.
translation.ja: だから私は 舞台で稼げないのね

translation.en: - Exactly. - And… But from the point of view of a musical about Eva Perón,
translation.ja: でもこの劇に対する 私の視点は

translation.en: I was completely correct. I was completely correct.
translation.ja: 全く間違ってなかった

translation.en: And then I went to see it one night with two guys who were Argentinian,
translation.ja: ２人のアルゼンチン人と 一緒に見た時

translation.en: and they were laughing so hard that we almost got kicked out of the theater.
translation.ja: 彼らは劇場から 追い出されるほど爆笑してた

translation.en: - I think Evita's not playing anymore. - Nah.
translation.ja: もう上映されないけど

translation.en: But it did play for a long time. I'm sure that every time I saw Stigwood after that, I said,
translation.ja: ロングランだった当時は ロバートを見る度に言ったの

translation.en: - I still think I'm right. -
translation.ja: “私は間違ってない”

translation.en: You know? It was making like a million dollars a minute.
translation.ja: 彼は大儲けしてたけどね

translation.en: Do you tend to look down at people?
translation.ja: いつも人を見下している？

translation.en: Do I tend to look down at people? You mean, am I a snob?
translation.ja: 私が偉そうってこと？

translation.en: There are certain kinds of snobberies that I think are bad.
translation.ja: 悪い意味で 見下している人もいる

translation.en: Of course, those are not the kind of snobberies I have. Okay?
translation.ja: でも私の場合は違う

translation.en: The kind of snobberies I have have nothing to do with,
translation.ja: 私が偉そうにする時は

translation.en: you know, Who is your father? Where'd you go to school? Where'd you grow up?
translation.ja: 相手の出生や 学歴を気にしない

translation.en: It has to do with, Do you agree with me about this?
translation.ja: 肝心なのは 意見が合うかどうか

translation.en: That's what it has to do with. Or, You think that? No.
translation.ja: もし違ったら相いれない

translation.en: Even though I know that people very frequently are very…
translation.ja: 私を頻繁に イラつかせる人がいる

translation.en: Not irritated. It's too mild of a word. …infuriated by me.
translation.ja: ぬるい表現ね 激怒させる人がいる

translation.en: Um, it does somewhat surprise me, because so what?
translation.ja: 激怒させる人がいる でも相手にしない

translation.en: Like, who am I? Am I making decisions for you?
translation.ja: 私に決定権があるの？

translation.en: I'm not in charge of anything.
translation.ja: そんな責任はない

translation.en: I understand being angry at me when I say things like, People should do this,
translation.ja: 私が人に指図して 世の中を変えられるなら

translation.en: or, This should happen, if people thought that I could change it.
translation.ja: 私が人に指図して 世の中を変えられるなら 怒る理由も分かる

translation.en: But if I could change it, I wouldn't be so angry.
translation.ja: でもそれができたら 苦労しない

translation.en: The anger is, I have no power, but I'm filled with opinions.
translation.ja: 怒るのは意見があるのに 権力がないからよ

translation.en: The subways are crummy, and they're dangerous.
translation.ja: 地下鉄は汚く 危険です

translation.en: You get pushed. You get shoved.
translation.ja: 人々は押し合い―

translation.en: Sometimes, you get mugged in the subway during the daylight.
translation.ja: 日中でも 盗難の被害に遭います

translation.en: I can remember when public transportation was one of the prides of New York.
translation.ja: かつての公共交通機関は 素晴らしかったけど

translation.en: What happened?
translation.ja: なぜ変わったの？

translation.en: Is New York better or worse today than when you first arrived?
translation.ja: ニューヨークは 良くなっている？ ニューヨークは 良くなっている？ アレック・ ボールドウィン

translation.en: Well, what you always hear about New York in the '70s was how horrible it was.
translation.ja: アレック・ ボールドウィン 70年代は最悪だったと 人は言う

translation.en: - Right. - New York was going bankrupt. I had no idea this was happening. - Right. - Okay? Because--
translation.ja: 誰も経済が破綻するとは 思わなかった

translation.en: You were having fun. Seeing rats, shattered benches in the park, graffiti.
translation.ja: ネズミを見て喜び 公園のベンチを壊してた

translation.en: - That was New York. - You were like, I'm having a great time.
translation.ja: そのとおり いい時代だった

translation.en: - Because-- - I'm drunk. I'm getting on that bus.
translation.ja: でも… 酔った時は 落書きなんて気にしない

translation.en: I don't care about graffiti. It's taking me where I wanna go.
translation.ja: 酔った時は 落書きなんて気にしない

translation.en: That's what New York looked like when you got there. You thought that was NY.
translation.ja: それがニューヨークだった

translation.en: There are people who arrive here now and think,
translation.ja: 今の人はこう考える

translation.en: New York, lawn chairs in Times Square.
translation.ja: “タイムズスクエアの 歩行者天国”

translation.en: When they take them out,
translation.ja: 折り畳み椅子がないと 混乱するわよ

translation.en: then people now will say, What happened to the lawn chairs?
translation.ja: 折り畳み椅子がないと 混乱するわよ “ここは ニューヨークじゃない”とね

translation.en: That was the real New York.
translation.ja: “ここは ニューヨークじゃない”とね

translation.en: Do you think they will still have the, uh, Times Square Café in the middle of the street?
translation.ja: タイムズスクエアのカフェは 今後も必要だと思う？

translation.en: I don't know if you're aware of this, Marty, because I know you've--
translation.ja: 知っているか 分からないけど…

translation.en: No. I don't go down below 57, no.
translation.ja: 僕は詳しくない

translation.en: All right, so up until, like, five minutes ago, 24 hours a day,
translation.ja: 少し前の話だけど タイムズスクエアの前は 24時間 舗装工事をしていた

translation.en: they were repaving these, whatever they call them, these cement things.
translation.ja: タイムズスクエアの前は 24時間 舗装工事をしていた セメントで塗り固めてね

translation.en: - Islands. - Yes, in the middle of Times Square.
translation.ja: セメントで塗り固めてね これを作った ブルームバーグ元市長は

translation.en: And then right before he was thrown out of office, finally,
translation.ja: これを作った ブルームバーグ元市長は

translation.en: I saw Bloomberg, uh, like, saying, And now these are permanent!
translation.ja: 辞任後に こう言った “これは永遠に残る”とね

translation.en: And I thought, Permanent? You hick.
translation.ja: 何も知らない田舎者ね

translation.en: - What's permanent in New York? - - - Really? Permanent! They're not permanent.
translation.ja: ニューヨークに “永遠”なんて存在しない

translation.en: However, that's the day I found out… What did that cost? $40 million.
translation.ja: しかも工事の費用は 4000万ドル

translation.en: - Oh! - $40 million. It wasn't Bloomberg's treat either, by the way.
translation.ja: もちろん彼の自腹じゃない

translation.en: - Okay? $40 million, taxpayer money. -
translation.ja: 納税者の4000万ドルなの

translation.en: $40 million for that. Okay? Because so many New Yorkers have said,
translation.ja: なぜなら 多くのニューヨーカーが タイムズスクエアに 寝転がりたいと言ったから

translation.en: You know what I hate? Not enough places to lie down in Times Square.
translation.ja: タイムズスクエアに 寝転がりたいと言ったから

translation.en: - Oh, sure. Hate that. -
translation.ja: そのとおりだ

translation.en: - It's unbearable! - Yeah, yeah, yeah. We're leaving. We can't take it anymore.
translation.ja: “寝転がれないなら この町から出ていく”ってね

translation.en: So the streets are completely packed
translation.ja: そのせいで 通りに埋め尽くされたのは

translation.en: with these horrible, I don't know what you'd call 'em, planters,
translation.ja: ひどい見た目の 植木みたいな物

translation.en: with fake plants, or they may be real plants. I don't know what they are.
translation.ja: 偽物か本物か 分からないけど

translation.en: Real plants, fake plants, I have no idea. What are plants doing in Times Square?
translation.ja: 植物を置くことに 何の意味があるの？

translation.en: And not just Times Square. I mean, The Bowery. It's the whole city.
translation.ja: 今や町中のどこにでもある

translation.en: They're all over the place. Plants, lawn chairs. You know, trinkets.
translation.ja: 植物や折り畳み椅子が 町を占領して

translation.en: Really, it looks like my grandmother's apartment.
translation.ja: まるで おばあちゃんの家よ

translation.en: I mean, you expect to see little photographs of grandchildren and…
translation.ja: もしかして孫の写真も必要？

translation.en: …little dishes of sour balls and…
translation.ja: 飾り皿やお菓子は？

translation.en: When New Yorkers hear about these budget cuts,
translation.ja: 予算削減を公表すれば

translation.en: they're gonna wanna know if New York City is going down the drain.
translation.ja: 市民はニューヨークが 崩壊すると考えます

translation.en: - Is it safe to say that New York-- - New York City isn't going down the drain.
translation.ja: それに… ニューヨークは崩壊しません

translation.en: Is it safe to say that New York City government will be less efficient,
translation.ja: 政府の機能が低下すれば

translation.en: the streets dirtier, citizens will have less protection from fire and criminals?
translation.ja: 道が汚れ 火事や犯罪の 被害が多くなりますよね？

translation.en: I said New York City is not going down the drain.
translation.ja: ニューヨークは絶対に 崩壊しません

translation.en: New York City is here to stay.
translation.ja: ニューヨークは絶対に 崩壊しません 元市長 エイブラハム・ビーム 元市長 エイブラハム・ビーム

translation.en: And it's still the greatest city in the world
translation.ja: 元市長 エイブラハム・ビーム 今後も世界一の町です

translation.en: and giving, even after this,
translation.ja: 予算を削減しても

translation.en: more services than any city in the world to its people.
translation.ja: 他のどんな町よりも 良い町になるでしょう

translation.en: I would really like to be like the Mayor of New York,
translation.ja: 〝フォード大統領から 市へ：勝手にくたばれ〞 私は市長になりたい

translation.en: but one of the bad things about mayoralty in New York,
translation.ja: 〝フォード大統領から 市へ：勝手にくたばれ〞 〝フォード大統領から 市へ：勝手にくたばれ〞 でも残念なことに

translation.en: which is a really hard job…
translation.ja: 本当に大変な仕事なの

translation.en: Mayor of New York is the second hardest job in the country.
translation.ja: 国内で２番目に大変な仕事よ

translation.en: - It starts early in the morning. - Mm.
translation.ja: 早朝から始まる

translation.en: It should be split in two, and I would be the night mayor.
translation.ja: だからシフト制にして 夜の市長になる

translation.en: I am volunteering for this. Someone else can be the day mayor.
translation.ja: 誰かが昼間を担当するなら

translation.en: I'll be the night mayor.
translation.ja: 夜は私がやる

translation.en: Uh, you know, I'll start around 4:00 and I'll go all night if you want.
translation.ja: 午後４時から夜通し働く

translation.en: I mean, the thing about New York is that a lot of things happen late at night.
translation.ja: ニューヨークは 夜に事件が起こるの

translation.en: What would you change about New York at night
translation.ja: 昼間の市長が寝ている間

translation.en: while, uh, the day mayor slept?
translation.ja: 夜の町をどう変えていく？

translation.en: The first thing I would change about New York, and not just me,
translation.ja: 最初に変えるところは もちろん地下鉄

translation.en: is the subway system.
translation.ja: もちろん地下鉄

translation.en: Okay? This is the first thing I would change about New York.
translation.ja: まずそれから変えていく

translation.en: A few weeks ago, I turn on the radio, which I listen to. WNS News.
translation.ja: 数週間前 ラジオを聞いていたの

translation.en: And they said, The L train… which is a train that goes from Brooklyn,
translation.ja: ブルックリンまで行く Ｌラインが

translation.en: The L train is closed today because there is a foul odor on the L train.
translation.ja: 悪臭のため 一時運行停止になった

translation.en: This was all day long. Every ten minutes, they kept saying,
translation.ja: １日中よ 10分ごとに アナウンスがあった

translation.en: There's a horrible smell on the L train. It's closed.
translation.ja: “悪臭で運転を 見合わせる”ってね

translation.en: And I thought to myself, The subway's closed because it smells horrible?
translation.ja: でもおかしいと思わない？

translation.en: - What does that even mean? Okay? -
translation.ja: そもそも意味が分からない

translation.en: Like, how much worse could it smell than it usually smells?
translation.ja: いつも臭いのに もっと臭くなる？

translation.en: Like, what could they… They don't know what this is.
translation.ja: 駅員は原因不明と言うけど

translation.en: And I thought, Who even noticed this? In other words, the train smells horrible.
translation.ja: むしろ いつも地下鉄は臭いのに

translation.en: Did someone say, You know, the train smells even worse than usual?
translation.ja: 誰が悪臭に 気付くことができる？

translation.en: I mean, they act like, Before this, you know, the smell was wisteria, there was an alpine village.
translation.ja: 以前は花の香りや 自然の匂いがしてた？

translation.en: I thought… And all day long, We can't find out what this smell is.
translation.ja: 調査員がずっと 原因を調査していて

translation.en: And then as the day went on… Now the L train is closed for five hours.
translation.ja: ５時間 運行は止まっていた

translation.en: …they said, Well… They went down, whoever tests this, and said, It doesn't smell as bad as it did.
translation.ja: そこで臭いが 和らいだことに気付いたの

translation.en: I thought, Of course not. It's been empty for five hours.
translation.ja: 乗客がいないんだから当然よ

translation.en: Let me tell you what smells horrible on the L train. The passengers!
translation.ja: 悪臭の原因は乗客に 決まってるでしょ

translation.en: - - Okay? Finally, they came down and said it was some kind of leaking motor oil.
translation.ja: オイル漏れのせいだと 言っていたけどね

translation.en: There was a… There was a comment on the news, too,
translation.ja: ニュースでも 取り上げられたが

translation.en: about the fact that they had tested it and it wasn't harmful.
translation.ja: 有害物質じゃないらしい

translation.en: No. It was the good motor oil they could smell.
translation.ja: 良いオイルだったのね

translation.en: It's like, after September 11th, like one hour later,
translation.ja: まるで９·11の 直後みたいな話

translation.en: when Christine Whitman, who was at that time the head of the EPA,
translation.ja: 環境保護庁長官の ウィットマンが

translation.en: went there, and she said, It's fine. - Yeah. - The air is fine.
translation.ja: “空気に問題はない”と 言ったの

translation.en: I remember saying to people, How could that possibly be?
translation.ja: 私は信じなかった

translation.en: Of course that's a lie.
translation.ja: うそだと思った

translation.en: And that wasn't… I mean, George Bush was president, so we were accustomed to a certain kind of lying,
translation.ja: 当時はブッシュが大統領で うそに慣れていたけど

translation.en: but I said, That's impossible.
translation.ja: おかしな話だった

translation.en: You know, you could smell what everyone called the dust for, like, 80 blocks.
translation.ja: ほこりと思われていたものは 広範囲に渡り臭っていた

translation.en: You know? And, uh… But she said it was fine.
translation.ja: でも彼女は安全だと主張した

translation.en: And now, of course, thousands of people are… - People have cancer - Have cancer,
translation.ja: しかしその結果 数千人が がんになった

translation.en: because it wasn't dust, first of all,
translation.ja: そもそも ほこりではない上―

translation.en: um, and it was not fine.
translation.ja: 安全でもなかった

translation.en: Isn't it nice to see the city so calm and…
translation.ja: 静かな町を見下ろす気分は？

translation.en: - City's calm 'cause no one's in it. -
translation.ja: 誰もいなくていい

translation.en: I mean, New York City this quiet? Something happened.
translation.ja: 静かになる時は 何かが起きた時よ

translation.en: I always remember, on September 11th, how quiet the city was.
translation.ja: ９·11の時は静かだった

translation.en: You know, I mean, after… If you didn't live right there. You know?
translation.ja: 現場以外の場所の話よ

translation.en: The only other time I heard New York City that quiet…
translation.ja: 他の事件でも一度 静まった

translation.en: And I lived in Midtown. It was never quiet.
translation.ja: 中心街は ずっとうるさいけどね

translation.en: …was when they were about to announce the OJ Simpson verdict.
translation.ja: Ｏ·Ｊ·シンプソンの事件よ

translation.en: The entire city apparently was watching television,
translation.ja: 全市民が中継を見守り

translation.en: and the entire city went dead silent…
translation.ja: 町全体が静まり返っていた

translation.en: until they announced the verdict.
translation.ja: 判決が下るまでね

translation.en: What was the other thing?
translation.ja: 他に撮りたい物は？

translation.en: The other thing was the rubber suit Godzilla that we were gonna do. Okay.
translation.ja: ゴジラの着ぐるみを 撮りたかった

translation.en: You know, Ishirō Honda! We're gonna step all over the city.
translation.ja: 本多猪四郎監督みたいに

translation.en: Right, you stroll down the, uh… Is that the Hudson?
translation.ja: 町を壊すんだ イースト川で 何か面白い物(ストライク)があれば…

translation.en: That's the East River. Okay. Yeah. So if anything strikes you…
translation.ja: イースト川で 何か面白い物(ストライク)があれば…

translation.en: I'm more worried that I will strike something than anything will strike me.
translation.ja: 面白い物より 模型を壊しそう(ストライク)で怖い

translation.en: Is there a difference between this model's representation of New York as it is now? Is there anything…
translation.ja: このレプリカと現在の町では 何が違う？

translation.en: When I was first here, which was not that long ago,
translation.ja: 最近 ここに来た時に

translation.en: I looked for my building where I live, which, at the time this was built,
translation.ja: 今住んでいるアパートを 探してみたの

translation.en: the building I live in was three warehouses made into an apartment building, and I managed to locate them.
translation.ja: レプリカが作られた当時は ３棟の倉庫だった

translation.en: You know, and you feel what you always feel. - I should've bought it then. You know? -
translation.ja: 10棟 買っておけば よかったわ

translation.en: I was trying to convince a friend's daughter to move back to New York from LA.
translation.ja: 友達の娘がニューヨークに 戻りたがっていた

translation.en: She said, I want to move back to New York, but I can't afford it.
translation.ja: “でも家賃が払えない”と 言うから

translation.en: So I said, Move back to New York. Let me tell you something.
translation.ja: “いいから来なさい”と 言ったの

translation.en: - No one can afford to live in New York. - Right.
translation.ja: 誰も家賃は払えない

translation.en: No one can afford to live in New York. Yet, eight million people do.
translation.ja: 払えないけど 800万人が住んでいる

translation.en: How do we do this? We don't know!
translation.ja: 工面の仕方は分からない

translation.en: It's a mystery to us.
translation.ja: 住民にも謎よ

translation.en: We don't have a clue.
translation.ja: お手上げ状態

translation.en: And that's just it too. We don't know, but we're still here.
translation.ja: なぜか分からないけど 住んでるの

translation.en: So you can come here without knowing how you're gonna live here,
translation.ja: とりあえず 引っ越してしまえば

translation.en: and somehow you will do enough things to live here.
translation.ja: 何とか生活できるようになる

translation.en: It's as simple as that.
translation.ja: 簡単よ

translation.en: - - Okay.
translation.ja: でしょ？

translation.en: When you leave New York or even if you stay for a little while somewhere else,
translation.ja: ニューヨーク以外の 場所で暮らすと

translation.en: you just can't get over the ease of daily life.
translation.ja: その快適さに驚く

translation.en: Like, you know, first, you move to an apartment, you think,
translation.ja: ニューヨークでは 引っ越しの度に頭を抱える

translation.en: Ugh! Where's the dry cleaner? Am I gonna ever find a dry cleaner?
translation.ja: ニューヨークでは 引っ越しの度に頭を抱える “クリーニング店はどこ？”

translation.en: Sometimes you never find one. Sometimes there isn't one!
translation.ja: 周辺に１店舗も ないかもしれない

translation.en: Or sometimes you go and… I know it's gonna be three months before I have such a fight,
translation.ja: あったとしても ３カ月で店員とけんかして

translation.en: - I won't be able to go in here ever again. -
translation.ja: 二度と行けなくなる

translation.en: Then you think, there are people who live in places
translation.ja: そこで気付くの

translation.en: where they just take the dry cleaning, they go to the dry cleaner.
translation.ja: “クリーニング店に 行きやすい町に”

translation.en: It's like a little errand.
translation.ja: “引っ越せばいい”ってね

translation.en: But everything in New York is like the Ring Cycle.
translation.ja: ニューヨークではまるで 「ニーベルングの指環」

translation.en: You know, everything in New York is an operatic thing.
translation.ja: 全てが壮大なオペラのよう

translation.en: It's… It's incredible problems.
translation.ja: 本当に大変よ

translation.en: So you realize that it's just so hard to live in New York
translation.ja: そこでニューヨークでの 生活は難しいと気付く

translation.en: that when people say, Why do you live in New York?
translation.ja: “どうして住むの？”と 聞かれても

translation.en: you really can't answer them,
translation.ja: 答えるのは難しい

translation.en: except you know that you have contempt for people who don't have guts to do it.
translation.ja: でも 住む根性がない人を 見下すのは楽しい

translation.en: You live in a place where things are just easily done,
translation.ja: “楽な町に住めていいよね”

translation.en: where people are nice to you,
translation.ja: “人も優しいし―”

translation.en: where no one's trying to cheat you every five seconds.
translation.ja: “５分ごとに 窃盗に遭わない”

translation.en: You call that grown- up life?
translation.ja: “それが大人の生活？“ってね

translation.en: The surprising thing to me is how many people who are in their twenties now
translation.ja: 驚くことがある よく20代の子が 私にこう言うの

translation.en: come up to me in the street and say,
translation.ja: よく20代の子が 私にこう言うの

translation.en: Fran, I wish that I'd lived in New York in the '70s. It seems like it was so much fun.
translation.ja: “70年代の方が 楽しそうだった”ってね

translation.en: Now, there's one thing I know for a fact, that when I was in my twenties, I wasn't going up to people my age,
translation.ja: でも私が20代だった頃は 今の私の年代の人に

translation.en: saying, I wish I'd lived in New York in the '30s. I never thought that.
translation.ja: “30年代が良かった”とは 言わなかった

translation.en: - - So, you know… So, like,
translation.ja: そうでしょう？

translation.en: since they know that I was here then, um, I'm like an eyewitness to this.
translation.ja: 70年代から住んでいるから 皆 話を聞きたがる

translation.en: It's like, I guess, if you were a Civil War buff, you know,
translation.ja: まるで南北戦争オタクが

translation.en: and you saw Abraham Lincoln, you would think, Oh! He was there. Let me ask him.
translation.ja: リンカーンに 質問するみたいよ

translation.en: If you don't have reservations, please wait outside.
translation.ja: 予約がない場合は 外でお待ちください 予約がない場合は 外でお待ちください マクシズ・ カンザス・シティ マクシズ・ カンザス・シティ

translation.en: We're gonna do a song now about a boy in New York City.
translation.ja: マクシズ・ カンザス・シティ これはニューヨークの 少年についての歌だ これはニューヨークの 少年についての歌だ

translation.en: Most of the people I knew who were financially more like me,
translation.ja: 私みたいにお金がない人は

translation.en: heat was a very big issue. We discussed it a lot.
translation.ja: 寒くて自分の家に いれなかった

translation.en: And I would go to Max's, and I would pick people up,
translation.ja: だからマクシズで ナンパしてたの

translation.en: - but, before, asking, Do you have heat? -
translation.ja: “家に暖房ある？”ってね

translation.en: And that would be something I found incredibly alluring.
translation.ja: それが最も 魅力的な条件だった

translation.en: All of a sudden, the person turned into a young Brigitte Bardot.
translation.ja: 急に相手がモデルに見える

translation.en: You have heat? Let's go.
translation.ja: “暖房があるなら 行くわ”ってね

translation.en: The New York Dolls, they were great, and so few people saw them.
translation.ja: ある日 ニューヨーク・ドールズが

translation.en: They used to perform at the Mercer Arts Center, which one day…
translation.ja: マーサー·アーツ· センターで演奏していたら…

translation.en: …just fell down. That's how New York used to be.
translation.ja: 突然 建物が倒壊した

translation.en: The Mercer Arts Center, we went all the time to see the Dolls,
translation.ja: ドールズ目当てに いつも演奏を 聞きに行っていた場所よ

translation.en: and other people, but especially the Dolls.
translation.ja: いつも演奏を 聞きに行っていた場所よ

translation.en: Um, and then, one day, it just fell down.
translation.ja: そこが突然なくなったの

translation.en: - Mm- hmm. - The building just fell down. That was the level of neglect.
translation.ja: でも誰も驚かなかった

translation.en: When people said, Did you hear the Mercer Arts Center fell down?
translation.ja: 事件のことを聞いても

translation.en: No one said, What are you talking about? Oh, it fell down.
translation.ja: 人々は“そう”と言うだけ

translation.en: That was the third… There were three buildings that fell down that year.
translation.ja: 同じ年に３件 倒壊したよね

translation.en: They fell down because no one took care of them. - Nobody did. - I mean, so…
translation.ja: 誰も管理してなかったからよ

translation.en: It was just the way it was. I never thought about it.
translation.ja: それが当時のニューヨーク

translation.en: There were numerous things I was thinking about, but New York getting better was not one.
translation.ja: 町の発展はどうでもよかった

translation.en: New York was great. That's why I came here!
translation.ja: 魅力的だから来たの

translation.en: But, you know, I didn't come here 'cause it was clean.
translation.ja: 清潔だから 来たわけじゃない

translation.en: I came from a clean place.
translation.ja: ここは汚い方

translation.en: I didn't think, Ah, I want to go to New York. It's so spotless.
translation.ja: 欠点がないわけじゃないのに

translation.en: I didn't come here 'cause it was safe. I came from a safe place.
translation.ja: わざわざ安全な場所から来た

translation.en: I didn't come 'cause it was dangerous.
translation.ja: 危険であることは 嫌だったけど

translation.en: I wasn't happy to be, you know, in danger, but I quickly acclimated.
translation.ja: 危険であることは 嫌だったけど すぐに順応して 70年代の習慣を受け入れた

translation.en: I have all the habits that I had in the '70s.
translation.ja: すぐに順応して 70年代の習慣を受け入れた

translation.en: For instance, I sit on the subway, I see people put their bag next to them and they leave it there.
translation.ja: 地下鉄でかばんを 脇に置いた人がいて驚いた

translation.en: I think, Are you out of your mind? It makes me want to steal it.
translation.ja: 私が盗もうかと思った

translation.en: You know, no matter what I'm holding… Really, it could be a pencil.
translation.ja: 私は何かを持っている時は たとえ鉛筆でさえも

translation.en: I have a death grip on it. You're not getting this pencil from me.
translation.ja: 死ぬ気で つかんでいた

translation.en: Like, I would never leave anything next to me. Never!
translation.ja: 絶対に脇に置かなかった

translation.en: And not because I think people might think it was a bomb,
translation.ja: 爆弾と思われるからじゃない

translation.en: but because someone's gonna take it! Of course they will.
translation.ja: 誰かが盗むからに決まってる

translation.en: - I've seen it. - That's what happens.
translation.ja: 日常茶飯事よ

translation.en: I mean, in 1971 or something like that,
translation.ja: 1971年かそのくらいの年に

translation.en: someone broke the windshield of my car,
translation.ja: 誰かが私の車の フロントガラスを割った

translation.en: which I still had my car from high school,
translation.ja: 高校の時からの愛用車よ

translation.en: um, and took, from the dashboard,
translation.ja: 高校の時からの愛用車よ そしてダッシュボードの 上にあった

translation.en: an apple and a pack of cigarettes that was on the dashboard.
translation.ja: リンゴとたばこを盗んだの

translation.en: Um, a pack of cigarettes then cost 50 cents.
translation.ja: たばこは１箱50セント

translation.en: Uh… An apple, one apple, ten cents.
translation.ja: リンゴは１つ10セント

translation.en: I call the police.
translation.ja: 警察を呼んだ

translation.en: I call them over, they were still on the street then, I said, Look.
translation.ja: 道端にいたからすぐに来た

translation.en: Someone smashed my windshield and took from my dashboard.
translation.ja: “フロントガラスが壊されて 盗難に遭った”と言ったら

translation.en: The cop goes, What did they steal?
translation.ja: “何を？”と聞かれた

translation.en: So I said, I had an apple, a pack of cigarettes.
translation.ja: “リンゴとたばこ”と 答えると

translation.en: And he goes, Well, what do you expect?
translation.ja: “当たり前だ”と言われた

translation.en: I mean, if you leave these valuable things
translation.ja: “人が見る場所に 何かを置けば”

translation.en: in full view of people, they're gonna break the windshield of your car!
translation.ja: “人が見る場所に 何かを置けば” “誰でも フロントガラスを割る”

translation.en: Who wouldn't do that?
translation.ja: “誰でも フロントガラスを割る”

translation.en: What are you, a moron?
translation.ja: “バカか？”ってね

translation.en: So, since he had a point, I didn't argue with him.
translation.ja: 結局 警察に同意したわ

translation.en: I realized, Yeah, well, what do you expect?
translation.ja: 確かに自業自得だった

translation.en: Apparently, there was that headline that said, you know,
translation.ja: フォード大統領が 市民に言ったのは

translation.en: President to New York: Go to hell, or whatever it was.
translation.ja: “地獄へ行け”だっけ？

translation.en: - Ford to New York: Drop dead. - Ford to New York: Drop dead.
translation.ja: “勝手にくたばれ”ね

translation.en: Meanwhile, who's dead?
translation.ja: 実際にくたばったのは？

translation.en: I also feel that, even though New York is not what it used to be,
translation.ja: ニューヨークは 変わってしまったけど

translation.en: I really can't imagine they'd let me live anywhere else.
translation.ja: ここ以外には住めないわ

translation.en: I just think they would get together, there'd be some sort of city council,
translation.ja: でも市議会委員が相談して

translation.en: and they would say, We've come to tell you, you have to leave. You can't stay here.
translation.ja: いつか“この町から 出て行け”と言われそう

translation.en: - That's what they kind of do with me. - Sorry. Time for you to leave.
translation.ja: 今がその状況だ そうね 帰りましょう
